document_title: Chronic enteritis: Causes, symptoms and treatment
subsection_content:
Ulcerative colitis has a common symptom of bleeding. In addition, patients may have mild fever, urgent diarrhea, tenesmus, bowel movements at night, weight loss, and abdominal cramps. Lesions in ulcerative colitis are often continuous, superficial ulcers and spread from the rectum up.
Crohn's disease has common symptoms of diarrhea lasting more than 6 weeks, and continuous diarrhea, in some cases more than 20 times a day, causing weight loss. Some other common symptoms are abdominal pain of varying nature, weight loss, and mild fever. Common location of damage in intermittent Crohn's disease: 75% in the ileum (last part of the small intestine), 30 - 40% of the small intestine alone, 15 - 25% only in the colon, 40 - 55% distributed both in the small intestine and colon. Up to 40% of CROHN patients have perianal manifestations such as excess skin folds, prolapsed hemorrhoids, and anal fistula. 35% may have fistulas between the digestive tract and organs in the body (bladder and vaginal fistulas) or leak into the skin, abdomen, or retroperitoneal space.(3)
In children, the disease often causes slow growth and delayed puberty. In addition, up to 25% of IBD cases manifest through non-gastrointestinal symptoms. Symptoms that may occur or affect patients outside the gastrointestinal tract include joint pain. A common case is pain in peripheral joints such as ankles, knees or small joints in the fingers. Men often have pain and limited movement of the spine. Other organs can occur in the eyes causing episcleritis and uveitis, in the skin causing erythema nodosum, dermatitis gangrene, leg ulcers, hepatobiliary manifestations causing obstructive jaundice, and hematologic manifestations. causes anemia…
